instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1297: What is A1297? A1297 is a model number for a 17 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Early 2009, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011 with EMC 2272, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2390, 820-2610, 820-2849, 820-2914..
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H_REG: What is PP3V42_G3H_REG? PP3V42_G3H_REG is another way to say PP3V42_G3H. PP3V42_G3H_REG and PP3V42_G3H are a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> has charger light but doesn't power on
threads.message:
Hi there,

I am a novice Mac repair hobbyist, so I apologize if I have missed something obvious.

I was given a broken 2009 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. I had green light on the charger, but it wouldn't power on. I opened it up and found some very noticeable water corrosion on <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>, particularly around pins 25 - 30. I cleaned the area and replaced <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>, but I lost pads 26 and 27, so replaced these with wire. After this, the computer booted up fine and worked without flaw. After about a week, I opened it up to replace the hard drive, but then it wouldn't boot anymore. Exactly the same symptoms as before. I thought I might have damaged something, but I think the failure was just coincidental. 

I have <SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_CONN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_REG</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_CPU_IMVP_ISNS</SIGNAL>, but I don't have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>, I don't have <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL> and I don't have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

I have watched Louis' video on this model (replacing <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>), but in his example he didn't have <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5_MCP</SIGNAL>, but I am reading 1.1V for <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5_MCP</SIGNAL>.
When power is connected, the MCP gets pretty warm too.

Does this sound like a dead MCP?

Thanks in advance for any advice you can provide.
Bruce

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> has charger light but doesn't power on
threads.message: If the MCP gets hot without the machine actually powering on then it is dead.
